translated: Sutra of the Wise and Foolish, Scroll 25
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter 29: Evil Conduct
Do not do any evil, practice all that is good, purify one's own mind,
this is the teaching of all Buddhas.

As for do not do any evil, the World-Honored Buddhas instruct later generations on the path of the Three Vehicles, not to attain the Way through cultivating evil, but to practice goodness and attain the Way on one's own. Therefore, it is said, do not do any evil.

As for practice all that is good, those who cultivate the Way universally cultivate goodness, adorning themselves with all virtues, avoiding evil and always cultivating goodness. What is called goodness is the wonderful medicine of calming and insight that burns away disordered thoughts.
Therefore, it is said, practice all that is good.

Purifying one's own mind means that the mind is the root of karma and attracts the roots of offenses. The knots of the hundred and eight heavy roots are difficult to untie and wrap around the mind. Desire, anger, and ignorance flourish, and arrogance, stinginess, jealousy, and various defilements are produced. Those with this illness have impure minds. Practitioners should uphold their will and refine their minds to prevent disordered thoughts. If they do not cease in this way, they will accomplish the roots of the Way. Therefore, it is said, purify one's own mind.

This is the Buddha's teaching means that the TathÄgata's teachings and precepts are not the same. Precepts are used to restrain the body and righteousness to gather the mind. The Buddha's appearance in the world is extremely difficult to encounter, just like the udumbara flower, which appears only once in many millions of eons.

Therefore, the TathÄgata's bequeathed teachings and transformations have been passed down from sage to sage until today. The prohibitions and admonitions should not be neglected, and giving should not be left undone. The reason I attained Buddhahood and became the king of the three thousand worlds is all due to the precepts and giving.
Therefore, it is said, this is the Buddha's teaching.
Generosity brings about blessings, do not harbor resentment and anger,
Use goodness to extinguish evil, with no remainder of desire, anger, or ignorance.

In the past, MahÄmaudgalyÄyana's cousin had abundant wealth and treasures, complete with the seven precious things, gold, silver, rare treasures, cat's eye gems, agate, pearls, tiger amber, storehouses overflowing with goods, servants and slaves beyond count.
At that time, MaudgalyÄyana went to his cousin's house and said to him:
I hear you are stingy and jealous, not fond of generosity.
The Buddha always expounds that when people are generous, they receive countless rewards.
If you are generous now, you will attain immeasurable blessings.
His cousin heard his elder brother's instruction, opened his storehouse to be generous, and newly established a storehouse hoping to receive its rewards.
Before a fortnight had passed, his wealth and treasures were exhausted, his old storehouse was empty, and his new storehouse had no rewards. He became distressed and said to his elder brother:

Previously, I saw the edict that giving brings great rewards, and I did not dare disobey the teaching. I exhausted the treasury and gave generously, reaching all the poor people of the past and future;
However, the wealth and treasures are exhausted, the old treasury is emptied, and the new treasury has no returns. Will I not be suspected and mistaken by my elder brother?
MaudgalyÄyana said:
Stop, stop, son of a great clan!
Do not speak these words.
Do not let the heretics and those of wrong views hear these coarse words.
If merit and virtue were to have form, the realm of space would not be able to contain it. I will now provisionally show you a small reward. If you wish to see it, follow me.
At that time, MaudgalyÄyana used his supernormal powers to take his younger brother by the hand and bring him to the sixth heaven.

There was a palace made of the seven treasures, with bathing pools in front and back, fragrant winds blowing from afar, treasuries overflowing beyond measure, tens of millions of female attendants, pure women without men, and no husband or master.
The younger brother said to MaudgalyÄyana:
What kind of palace is this, so lofty and magnificent?
I do not see any men, only women.
MaudgalyÄyana told his younger brother:
Go ask them yourself, and you will know.
He then went to ask:
Heavenly maidens, you should know!
I have something to ask, please explain it for me.
The heavenly maidens asked:
What doubts do you have that you wish to ask about?
He replied:
What kind of palace is this, composed of the seven treasures, lofty and magnificent, suspended in the sky?
Who has such virtue to enjoy blessings within it?
Please explain my doubts so that I am forever free from hesitation.
The heavenly maidens replied:
Don't you know?
We have been here for many years, enjoying natural blessings without any troubles. If you want to know about our husbands, they are in our hearts and I will now tell you.

In the realm of the country of KÄpi in JambudvÄ«pa, there is a disciple of ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha named MaudgalyÄyana. He has a virtuous younger brother who is a wealthy elder, who delights in giving generously andå‘¨çª®æ¿Ÿä¹, after his death he will be reborn here, becoming my husband, and the reward for giving generously to me and my family will be a palace of the seven treasures.
When the man heard this, a good thought arose in him, and he returned to his elder brother and fully told him his feelings.
MaudgalyÄyana said:
How is it, son of a good family?
When a person gives generously, will there be a reward?
Or will there be no reward?
The younger brother felt ashamed and repented, and returned to the world to give generously widely without slacking off.
Therefore it is said, By giving generously, one obtains the reward of blessings.
As for not harboring anger, if a person harbors poison and keeps it inside, waiting for others' faults and troubling others' goodness, such a person cannot be associated with;

It is like covering fire with ashes. Although the eyes do not see it, if stepped on it will burn the feet. If the body is not guarded, rashly violating the precepts, the mind may be bold at the time but will unknowingly suffer harm.

People have been harmed since ancient times. Some harbor resentment beforehand, some suddenly give rise to anger. Those who suddenly give rise to anger are still forgivable, but those who harbor resentment beforehand find it difficult to be close to.
Why is this so?

When people secretly scheme, there must be harm and destruction. Foolish crowds follow each other, eventually leading to evil calamities. Externally proclaiming secrecy, internally sharing feelings, mutually praising each other, becoming evil friends, things go against wishes and eventually lead to ruin. Family members and wealth all enter the government, despised by people, and their voices are hated.
Therefore, it is said, Do not harbor anger and resentment.

Using goodness to extinguish evil, with no remainder of desire, anger, or delusion, refers to the so-called goodness of the factors of the noble eightfold path. Riding this path, like the waters of the four great rivers, one cuts off the flow and has nothing to fear or difficulty. Extinguishing and crossing over the various evil parts, preventing them from being reborn, with calamities vomiting the poison of desire, anger, and delusion arising, uprooting the three roots and planting the three karmas, looking up to cultivate the contemplation of the path and progress towards the four paths, what difficulty is there to accept?
Therefore it is said, using goodness to extinguish evil, with no remainder of desire, anger, or delusion.
Walk alone, do not follow fools, if you wish to be in a group, follow the wise.
The wise extinguish evil, like a crane selecting milk to drink.

As for walking alone, do not follow fools, the so-called walking alone means being in a quiet place with a scattered mind, contemplating the roots of goodness and focusing the mind in front, if you wish to be in the same place, you should associate with good friends, do not associate with bad friends, therefore it is said, walk alone, do not follow fools.

Those who wish to follow the multitude should follow the wise. In the world, there are many people who admire and follow the wise, those who are diligent, have deep eloquence, and are able to expound the teachings without weariness. Therefore, it is said, Those who wish to follow the multitude should follow the wise.

The wise eliminate evil. The wise are clear about the past and present, and what they say must be helpful. Day and night, they diligently contemplate the Way and accept the teachings spoken by the wise. With wholesome merits, they eliminate all evil. Therefore, it is said, The wise eliminate evil.

Like a crane selecting milk to drink. In the past, there was someone who caught many cranes and raised them with milk, and they grew up and had offspring, their numbers becoming limitless. The method of raising cranes is to mix water with milk for them to eat. The cranes' usual habit is that when they are about to eat, they blow out air from their nostrils, separating the water and eating only the milk. Even though the birds are dull-witted, they are still able to distinguish the water from the milk.
Can the bhiká¹£us of today not be like this?
One should select what is good and remove what is evil, just as that crane deeply knows what is good and what is bad.
Therefore it is said, Like a crane selecting milk to drink.
Observing the world's various changes, knowing the traces of dharmas arising and ceasing,
The sages do not delight in the world, the foolish do not dwell with the wise.
As for observing the world's various changes, the so-called world has three levels:
First, the world of vessels; second, the world of skandhas; third, the world of sentient beings.

These three worlds are the prison cell for storing illnesses, solid inside and out, not curable by doctors. Internally, the four hundred and four illnesses arise simultaneously, externally, poisonous creatures such as vipers, centipedes, scorpions, tigers, and wolves bite and sting. The various changes are not the same, with different kinds of water, fire, thieves, enemies, and so forth secretly coming to harm.
Therefore it is said, Observing the world's various changes.
Knowing the traces of the arising and cessation of dharmas, knowing the traces of the arising and cessation, there are two matters:
First, the traces of bonds, second, the traces of aggregates.
Being able to extinguish these matters is in accord with the unconditioned, therefore it is called, knowing the traces of the arising and cessation of dharmas.

The sages do not delight in the world, the foolish do not dwell with the sages. The sages eternally extinguish evil and do not dwell among the common people. When a crane flies, it soars high and does not delight in a hill of tombs. A gibbon prefers purity and does not dwell in a latrine. The sages are also like this, not dwelling among the common people and sharing their light;
The foolish prefer evil and do not dwell with the sages.
Therefore it is said, the sages do not delight in the world, the foolish do not dwell with the sages.
Understanding and knowing the taste of mindfulness, contemplating the meaning of rest,
Without heat or hunger, one should take the taste of the Dharma.

As for understanding and knowing the taste of mindfulness and waiting, one has gone through countless births and deaths, yet has never obtained this taste of mindfulness and waiting. The world has many sweet and wonderful flavors, such as sugarcane and grapes, which are innumerable and cannot be described. One enjoys them day and night without ever being satisfied;

However, this does not lead to the unconditioned. The taste of mindfulness and waiting has never entered the mouth. If one encounters it once, one will never be hungry or thirsty again. As for the other flavors, one goes through birth and death, falls into the three evil paths, and finds it truly difficult to seek a way out.
Therefore, it is said to understand and know the taste of mindfulness and waiting.

As for contemplating the meaning of rest, the practitioner, having already focused single-mindedly, contemplates meditation, and the Dharma contemplated by the mind is never mistaken or confused. From beginning to end, one does not recognize its sequence. Therefore, it is said to contemplate the meaning of rest.

The thought of no heat and no hunger means that craving is heat, anger is heat, delusion is heat, hunger and thirst are heat, and being able to cut off this hunger and thirst is a very difficult matter;
Even if one drinks the four great oceans of water, wanting to quench one's thirst, it has never been seen.
If one wants to remove one's thirst and forever prevent its arising, there is only the pure taste of the eight liberations that can eliminate the root of all thirst.
Therefore it is said, The thought of no heat and no hunger.

One should take the taste of the Dharma means that the taste of the Dharma, among all gifts the gift of the Dharma is supreme, among all tastes the taste of the Dharma is supreme, one who attains this taste, the Dharma body is not apart from the root of suffering, and cuts off the afflictions of worldly hunger and thirst. If a person wants to cultivate and seek liberation, but cannot obtain the taste of the nectar of the ultimate essentials, how can one sit peacefully in inaction?
If one does not diligently seek to attain the path, it is very difficult.
Therefore it is said, One should take the taste of the Dharma.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
People do not harm their minds, nor do they destroy their intentions,
Using goodness to forever extinguish evil, they do not worry about falling into evil paths.

People do not harm their minds, nor do they destroy their intentions means that when people first establish practices, they first learn wholesome dharmas. Their initial intention is hesitant, sometimes believing and sometimes not believing. Those whose minds are courageous hear and immediately believe and understand, while those whose minds are doubtful do not penetrate the Dharma. Such people will certainly go through birth and death, with billions of Buddhas passing by without being liberated.
If one harms their mind but does not destroy their intention, then attaining the Way will be very easy.

If people wish to cultivate and study, they will attain it by concentrating their minds. It is like an individual who hears that there is a Dharma in another place, but there are many difficulties along the way and no way to pass through. If they single-mindedly think of it, their form and mind will reach it.
Why is this known?
It is like a person who has attained spiritual powers, whose mind thinks of a form and it follows. Therefore it is said, People do not harm their minds, nor do they destroy their intentions.

By completely extinguishing evil, one does not worry about falling into evil paths. When a person practices diligently and reveres the Way, worldly views may appear before them. Although they have wholesome roots, these are worldly and defiled practices. If one does not give rise to attachment and seek higher states, such a person will never worry about falling into evil destinies.
Therefore it is said, By completely extinguishing evil, one does not worry about falling into evil paths.
If a person wishes to refine their spirit, they must repeatedly cultivate and polish it.
The wise are easily adorned and are called heroes of the world.
Those who can be close to them are at ease and have no worries or troubles.

People who want to refine their spirits must repeatedly practice carving. Old students are empty outside and full inside. Some hide in the mountains, some pretend to be crazy and wander the world. Although their practices are different, what they save is the same. This does not take form and vessel, this purely refines the spirit and intention, the practice person temporarily manifests a thousand turns and a hundred transformations, and must set up skillful means to guide sentient beings to the room of a hundred refinements;
The so-called room is the city of nirvana, emptiness, and inaction.
Therefore it is said, people who want to refine their spirits must repeatedly practice carving.

The wise are easily carved and adorned, and are called the heroes of the world. Those with sharp and quick faculties speak and become rules. They must attain the four unobstructed abilities: the ability to expound the meaning, the ability to expound the Dharma, the ability to expound the words, and the ability to expound in response. The ability to expound the meaning and the ability to expound the Dharma include internal dharmas, while the ability to expound the words and the ability to expound in response include external dharmas.
Therefore it is said, The wise are easily adorned, and are called heroes in the world.

Those who can be close to them are at ease and have no worries or distress. When a person observes deportment in their movements, coming and going, turning around, going back and forth, they all observe deportment without losing propriety, just like various flowers blooming in competition, with their fragrance spreading far.

Those who practice in this way, with precepts, hearing, giving, virtue, all the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gates, and concentration that is not scattered, can be close to this without any violation or loss, and can then accomplish the practice of the holy ones without outflows.
Therefore it is said, Those who can be close to them are at ease and have no worries or distress.
Those who permanently cease and have no faults are gentle and not impetuous,
Blowing away all evil dharmas like the wind dropping leaves.

Forever at rest, without fault, gentle, not abrupt means that one's faculties are complete, without overflow, one's speech is focused and correct, one's words are not abrupt, and one's deportment and etiquette are without error. Such a person is without peer and without fault. Therefore it is said, Forever at rest, without fault, gentle, not abrupt.

Blowing away evil dharmas, like wind removing leaves means that the practitioner's intention is firm and unmoving, their faith is steadfast and not violated even slightly, they remove evil dharmas and progress in goodness day by day, and they adorn themselves day and night to prevent dust. Just as iron produces rust that is polished away to reveal the brightness, so too the heavy defilements of the human mind are illuminated by wisdom. Therefore it is said,
Blowing away evil dharmas, like wind removing leaves.
Without reason, fearing that person, slandering and defaming the pure one,
Soon encountering the power of evil, like smoke and clouds blown by the wind.

Without reason, fearing those people, slandering and defaming the pure ones, the foremost practice of those who study is to eliminate defilements. Practitioners remove impurities and cultivate only purity, their merits are full, so what is there to fear about not understanding? Those who are free from stinginess and jealousy, who revere the roots of the Way and suddenly awaken on their own, this is because they thoroughly understand the profound essentials.
Pure people have no afflictions, but the foolish slander and defame them, considering them impure. Slandering and defaming the sages results in the sin of indiscriminate killing.
This is due to the accumulation of meritorious rewards and practices.
Therefore it is said: Without reason, fearing those people, slandering and defaming the pure ones.

Following evil, one obtains its power, like smoke and clouds blown by the wind. Worldly people are deluded and take evil as wonderful, thus calamities gradually enter Mount Tai, creating the sins of hell, hungry ghosts, and various animal realms. Therefore it is said: Following evil, one obtains its power, like smoke and clouds blown by the wind.
As for the conduct of people, each knows for themselves what is good and what is evil.

As for the conduct of people, each knows for themselves what is good and what is evil. Those who do evil know they are evil, and those who do good know they are good. Even if one does good or evil without knowing it, one will receive a twofold retribution. Those who do good will receive endless blessings, and those who do evil will receive a twofold punishment. The pure will receive pure conduct, and the impure will receive impure conduct.

When one is about to die, good and evil are clearly distinguished. If the spirit is welcomed, one will see palaces, houses, gardens, ponds, and gods who are not confused. Robes and garments will naturally be worn on the body, and heavenly maidens will surround one, sharing entertainment together. One will see the light shining unobstructed.

When a person who has accumulated evil is about to die, their consciousness becomes confused, and they only see great fires, swords, halberds, and vultures, wild foxes, rÄká¹£asas, demons, tigers, wolves, and vicious beasts. They also see sword mountains, knife trees, thorns, pits, and evil ghosts surrounding them.
Therefore it is said, Good is good, and evil is evil.
When a person does evil, they will later receive retribution. If they do not do evil,
they will have nothing to worry about later.

As for when a person does evil, they will later receive retribution, it means that when a person does evil, they invite misfortune and trouble upon themselves. Neither their parents, siblings, nor relatives will take on their punishment.

If they do not do evil, they will not receive retribution later. Such a person, when born, will encounter sages and receive their blessings. Neither their parents nor siblings will share in their good fortune. Their mind is naturally pure and does not trouble others. They themselves practice purity and receive their own retribution.
Therefore it is said, When a person does evil, they will later receive retribution themselves. Having not done evil, there is nothing to worry about later.
Understanding one's own purity and impurity, why worry about others' purity?
The foolish do not refine themselves, like iron drilling pure steel.

Understanding one's own purity and impurity, why worry about others' purity? If one is oneself pure and able to cause others to practice purity, how can one who does not practice equally cause others to attain pure practice?
Therefore it is said, Understanding one's own purity and impurity, why worry about others' purity?

The foolish do not refine themselves, like iron drilling pure steel. The foolish exhaust themselves all day long without reaching the end. What they create in one day leads to falling into the abyss for eternal kalpas. Even if they encounter sages, they are not saved. It is like iron drilling pure steel, reaching the point where it cannot be obtained.
Therefore it is said, The foolish do not refine themselves, like iron drilling pure steel.
If the eyes see what is not wrong, the wise seek means,
The wise live well in the world, and also do not do many evils.

As for If the eyes see what is not wrong, if a person practices diligently and does evil, if the eyes see forms and do not give rise to eye-consciousness, whether good or ugly, the mind is all equal. Even if one sees good forms, one does not give rise to attachment, and even if one sees bad forms, one does not harbor sorrow. Therefore it is said, If the eyes see what is not wrong.

As for The wise seek means, seeing those eye forms, knowing them to be not real, to be dharmas of grinding to a halt, changing and not abiding, those who are born have an end, and those who are constant also cease. The foolish play and practice, while the wise laugh at them. Therefore it is said, The wise seek means.

The wise live well in the world, and do not do many evil things. The wise give teachings and skillful transformations in many ways, preventing evil in the formless, nurturing blessings in the natural, practicing without burdening the world, and teaching without harming the body.
Circling in the world, their life is short, seeing shortness as shameful, seeing length as not boasting, living out their life in the world, never doing evil.
Therefore it is said, the wise live well in the world, and do not do many evil things.
Merchants on the road are afraid, with few companions and much merchandise,
Passing through dangerous places, yet having the worry of a broken axle.

Merchants on the road are afraid, with few companions and much wealth. In the past, there were many merchants who ventured on the road, passing through the wilderness and dangerous places, with many robbers on the road, unable to escape on their own, with no provisions for their wealth and treasures, and no weapons to defend themselves with their companions. The travelers were few and the wealth and treasures were extremely abundant, their minds were fearful and their consciousnesses were agitated.
There was a wise one who said to his companions:
Do not be afraid, I will devise a plan to escape this difficulty.
The minds of the people were correct and they were able to avoid danger.
Therefore it is said, merchants on the road are afraid, with few companions and much wealth.

Passing through dangerous places, but having the worry of a broken axle. On a dangerous road, not encountering a good companion, abandoning the great road and following the narrow path, not reaching the destination but encountering a broken cart in the middle, the previous companions not looking back, the later companions abandoning each other.

Therefore, the World-Honored One uses this as a metaphor, wanting later generations to deeply understand sin and merit. Those who receive the teaching have no obstruction even as small as a hair, and those who expound the teaching do not waste their efforts.
Therefore, it is said, Having passed through dangerous places, there is still worry about the axle breaking.
If one has a body but no wounds, one will not be harmed by poison.
Poison cannot do anything to a wound. If one is without evil, there is nothing to create.
Just as Devadatta, while in RÄjagá¹›ha, gave rise to a mind of harm, later his actions were exposed and the whole country heard about it. At that time, King AjÄtaÅ›atru said to Devadatta:
You should leave the country and do not stay here. The sixteen great countries all know about this.
How can there be Devadatta here, creating various evils and giving rise to a mind of harm towards the TathÄgata?

Devadatta, hearing this, became inwardly sorrowful and uneasy. His mind was not at peace. He returned to his own country. His old enmity was not yet extinguished. He was bound by the fetters of anger. He suddenly intruded into the Bodhisattva's palace and said to GopÄ:
I now take you and make you my first wife. I wonder if the Holy Maiden will agree to this?
When GopÄ heard this, she said to Devadatta:
Extend your right hand. I want to grasp it.

Devadatta immediately extended his hand for her to grasp. He grabbed his wrist, and the bones shattered. Blood flowed from his five fingers. At that time, he fainted for a long time before regaining consciousness.
GopÄ said:

Apart from the power of SiddhÄrtha, there is no one who surpasses me. If you were to grasp and hold onto me, your body would be shattered and rotten, worse than dust and mist. It would be like a powerful person crushing a thousand trees with a finger. What difficulty would there be in doing as you wish?

At that time, Devadatta entered the palace and sat on the Bodhisattva's bed. The palace ladies all disliked him and grabbed him, throwing him under the bed, injuring his left hip and making it impossible for him to walk. His family carried him back to his own house.
All the ÅšÄkyas disliked him and came to tell him:
You, Devadatta, should change and repent to the Buddha.
When Devadatta heard this, he secretly devised a clever deception, secretly making iron claws and smearing poison on them, outwardly appearing gentle while inwardly harboring anger.
At that time, Devadatta remembered what the Buddha had said:
The Gautama Åšramaá¹‡a always says this:
'If the body has no wounds, it will not be harmed by poison. Poison is powerless against wounds, and without evil there is nothing to create.'
I will now go and pretend to repent, scratch his foot with my claws, and let the poison spread and take his life.
The people carried him in a palanquin to where the World-Honored One was. Three times seven fathoms away from the World-Honored One, he said to the people on the left and right:
Put me down on the ground. I wish to walk on foot.
He then got down on the ground.
At that moment, fierce boiling water gushed out from the ground, wrapped around his body, and he was about to enter hell.
Therefore it is said, If one has a body but no wounds, one will not be harmed by poison. Poison is powerless against wounds.
Having done many evil deeds, one will certainly create burdens for oneself.
Practicing goodness and spreading kindness and virtue, this matter is very difficult.

Many who engage in various evils will certainly create burdens for themselves. In the world, there are many who spread evil and harm themselves, not in accord with the noble truths. Butchers, fishermen, hunters, pig farmers, chicken keepers, setting up nets and snares to catch deer, thieves killing thieves, bound to prison guards, candÄla caste using strings and nets, such evil deeds of sentient beings are innumerable. Such types will certainly create troubles for themselves. After death, they will enter hell and experience pain beyond measure. Therefore, it is said, Many who engage in various evils will certainly create burdens for themselves.

To give good deeds and spread kindness is a matter of great difficulty. People can reflect on the good and evil karmic retributions of their past and future lives, widely giving to the poor, sacrificing their own flesh and wealth to give to others. This is a matter of great difficulty.
Therefore, it is said, To give good deeds and spread kindness is a matter of great difficulty.
Excellent! Those who cultivate goodness, excellent! Those who do great evil,
It is easy for the wicked to do evil for themselves, but difficult for the wicked to do good.

It is good to cultivate goodness. For good people, cultivating good conduct should come naturally. Those who do evil should not be associated with. Good people are protected by the Buddhas and cherished by the gods and people of the world. Wherever they go, they will never be apart from good spiritual friends. Therefore it is said, It is good to cultivate goodness.

It is good to be very evil. For people, doing evil increases without decrease, just like creeping vines that grow without being planted. Even if the ground is cleared and the place is pure, they still grow without ceasing. Therefore it is said, It is good to be very evil.

It is easy for the wicked to do evil for themselves, but difficult for the wicked to do good. It is like the kind of people who always carry dead bodies and abandon them in the charnel ground, their minds always delighted without fear or avoidance, their minds doubly joyful and entertained by themselves;
It is like a prison warden guarding shackles, doing evil day and night, considering himself honorable.

The wise and holy view these various changes as great troubles. A person sentenced to death is about to be executed in the capital. With every step he takes, he is getting closer to the place of death. How can one crave and yearn for the bitter suffering of the three realms?
Therefore, it is said, It is easy to do evil for oneself, but difficult for an evil person to do good.
The foolish think they are right, but evil is not yet ripe.
When evil ripens and is fulfilled, all suffering also ripens.

The foolish think they are right, but evil is not yet ripe. Foolish people think to themselves that what they do is correct, and that what others do is all illegal. They see those who do good and hate them together. The roots of sin are complete, and the foolish mind is fully ripe. Only then do they know that what they do is wrong.

Now, the evil I have created is not done by my parents, nor is it done by my brothers and relatives. I alone receive the punishment, and regret is of no avail. It is not done by gods, ghosts, Å›ramaá¹‡as, or brÄhmaá¹‡as. I now know for myself the root of sin. I do not blame heaven above nor the earth below. I willingly accept the punishment. Knowing what to do is of no avail.
Therefore it is said, The foolish think they are right, as if evil has not yet matured.

When evil has matured and is full, all suffering is also received means that a person who has accumulated sins enters hell and receives retribution. Thirteen kinds of flames wrap around their body. They die and revive, but cannot die. They must repay their past sins until they are exhausted without remainder, and only then do they leave;

If they are born as animals, they are obscured by foolishness and do not recognize the true path. Their backs are covered with sores, their noses are pierced, their heads are shackled, and their hands and feet are chained;

If they are born as hungry ghosts, they are hungry and thirsty day and night, with stomachs as big as Mount Tai and throats as thin as needles. Their bodies are forty li long, with a thousand openings in every inch;
If reborn among humans, they are poor, lowly, destitute, with clothes that do not cover their bodies and food that does not fill their mouths.
Therefore it is said, When evil is fully ripened, suffering also ripens.
The wise see evil, but are not ripened by evil,
Just as evil is not ripened, the evil one observes their evil.

The wise see evil, but are not ripened by evil means that practitioners see those who do evil and admonish them in a timely manner, saying this is not a wonderful practice, transmigrating in birth and death it is very difficult to escape, creating the fundamental causes of sin in the three evil paths. Therefore it is said, The wise see evil, but are not ripened by evil.
Just as evil is not ripened, the evil one observes their evil means that when a person does evil later they feel remorse:
